title: Thursday, 8th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Okay, here we are, good morning, welcome.

BE11:03am

And apologies, we're a tad disorganised this morning.

BE11:04am

Having spent too much time chasing a story already noted on the right.

11:03 am
IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 380.20, up 15 (+4.11%), High: 392.00, Low: 361.50, Volume: 3.35m
BE11:04am

Better known as "formerly Regus".

BE11:04am

And it appears that, if the rumours are accurate, we'll have to give the scoop to something called Wall Street Wires.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

(Nope, me neither.)

BE11:04am

http://wallstreetw...s-various-bidders/

BE11:05am

TIWG Plc, a £3bn company, is said to be working with an investment bank on a sale, and in talks with various bidders.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

That's the relevant par amid a load of filler about trends and chartism and such.

BE11:05am

It isn't a lot of info, and includes a typo in the company name, which isn't the kind of thing that establishes confidence in a rumour.

BE11:06am

However, it might be wrong to jump to conclusions. It's possible that cynicism here might be misplaced.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

To that end, we can add a bit of flesh to the rumour.

BE11:06am

RAW tho. RAW. RAW RAW RAW.

BE11:06am

The talk here is private equity.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Specifically, Apollo private equity.

BE11:07am

With a live sale process being run by Lazard.

BE11:07am

And with Morgan Stanley involved on the buyer side, it has been rumoured.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

That is what's being talked about in the market today, to be clear.

BE11:08am

We have calls in with various people familiar with things but are yet to hear anything back.

BE11:09am

That RAW warning is up there for a reason. In fact, it often doesn't make the transcript so I'll put it in as a graphic too.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

BE11:09am

Now, there are a number of points to make here.

BE11:09am

The first is to note the existence of Mark Dixon. Founder, CEO, Executive Director and 27.7 per cent shareholder.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

He last sold in September 2016, taking 4% off the table. But there's no signal I can remember that he's keen to step back from the business.

BE11:10am

The second thing to note is that IWG continues to buy back its own shares.

BE11:10am

As in, as recently as today: http://www.investe...1706080700024689H/

11:11 am
BE11:11am

It's hard to read that though. The rules on whether a company is conflicted from buybacks with inside information depends on who has authority to execute the buyback, if I remember correctly.

BE11:11am

Thirdly, it's an open question whether IWG to PE makes sense.

BE11:12am

It's number one by a mile in a office space thing, but has largely been a cost saving story in recent years.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Chart via JP Morgan.

BE11:12am

BE11:12am

Nearly all those sites are plain old Regus Express units, though it does have a few other brands that make up about 100 properties.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Of most interest to investors has been Spaces, its WeWork Premium clone for co-working types. There are two-dozen of those.

BE11:13am

And a reminder that Softbank's recent investment in WeWork valued it at about $20bn.

BE11:13am

It's also worth noting that, at first glance, IWG looks like a perfect PE target. But it's quite a bit more complicated than that.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The balance sheet shows barely any debt, against a 2.5x ND/EBITDA covenant.

BE11:13am

But Dixon has kept net debt to minimal levels because of the high level of leverage created by operating leases.

BE11:14am

Which is a problem, at least optically. After 2019, IFRS 16 accounting rules mean all operating leases have to be capitalised

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And while 2016 leverage appears to be 0.4 times, it's actually 3.2 times once you bundle in lease obligations. Include the termination periods -- as IFRS demands -- and that rattles up to nearly 4 times.

BE11:15am

So, does Dixon want to spend the next few years fighting about appropriate leverage levels in a cyclical business? Or would he rather not?

BE11:15am

Dunno. Here's an old Cazenove note.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Could IWG be worth more as a private business?
While there are benefits to being a publicly listed company we believe that there are also logical arguments as to why it may be able achieve a higher valuation as a private firm.

BE11:16am

Accelerate investment profile, especially in Spaces locations
IWG is currently by far the global leader in flexible workspace; however, with the strong growth in market demand and in particular the growth in the premium, co-working segment IWG is keen to invest to capture as much market share as possible. We believe management is very focused on medium-term shareholder value; however, as a listed company there is some pressure to balance short-term profits and cash, vs. an expanded investment programme which depresses short-term profits and cash flows but enlarges the business and long-term cash flows. This is particularly the case with IWG’s co-working brand, Spaces. We see the large potential for Spaces if it can assert itself as one of the leading players in the industry, in a similar ilk to WeWork. However, we believe this would require material investment to increase brand awareness and to invest in a large number of locations which would initially be loss making.

BE11:16am

Ability to bear leverage
The core of IWG's offering is to remove the fixed long-term lease liability from a client, and replace it with a series of short-term leases which are an off-balance-sheet and lower-cost option for the client. The impending implementation of IFRS 16, which will bring operating leases on balance sheet, may cause some investors to view IWG as over-levered. The public markets have an aversion to relatively high leverage due to the perception of risk, whereas a private business IWG could deal with the economic reality of its SPV structure.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Complexity
IWG is a relatively unique listed company, and with the lack of frequent third party data on the industry it can be difficult for investors to track, causing a higher cost of equity. Moreover, the understanding and comfort around the SPV structure for individual centres materially changes the investment case, and it is difficult to fully understand the terms and conditions of these from the outside.

BE11:16am

Interesting, right?

BE11:16am

Anyway, shares are up 3.5% live.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

*IWG RESPONDS TO EMAIL REGARDING SALE TALKS REPORT

BE11:17am

*IWG DOESN'T COMMENT ON MARKET SPECULATION, SPOKESPERSON SAYS

BE11:17am

Thumbs up

11:19 am
BE11:19am

I'm going to go out on a limb here and say that commenting on market speculation is sometimes quite a useful thing to do. However, for as long as companies adopt the opposite strategy, it means we're justified in taking the more aggressive approach applied above.

undefined
BE11:20am

And onto the more prosaic business of the day.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Triple threat Thursday, of course, except the election isn't really a today threat.

BE11:22am

We're under broadcasting rules now, so the most we can write until 10pm is "people go to the polls".

BE11:22am

FTSE responding by doing nothing.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Flat at 7,476.

BE11:24am

And sorry @Dodgson, I didn't get the chance to find a picture this morning. Head to the #dogsatpollingstations hashtag if you want something to look at while I type.

BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live thing with the live markets and etc.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Heading into news .........

Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 410.40, down 21.3 (-4.93%), High: 434.80, Low: 406.40, Volume: 2.67m
BE11:27am

Results beat consensus, outlook looks solid enough.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Gists from the sellside is that there's nothing much wrong but nothing much to get excited about either.

BE11:28am

Tone understandably cautious.

BE11:28am

The Board is confident of delivering its growth expectations in the coming year, despite wider economic uncertainty fuelled by the result of last year’s EU referendum

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:29am

Sorry, no, here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:30am

Implication for forecasts. Auto Trader notes industry expectation of flat or declining new car sales after a period of strong sustained growth. The strength of prior year new car sales should continue to fuel used car sales growth. Expectation for ARPR growth is for a return to the 2016 rate of £130 plus – more a reflection on the robustness of the 2016 growth rate, which is a hard rate to replicate. Overall operating margins are expected to rise further. We do not anticipate consensus numbers varying on the basis of todays’ news and commentary. Nor do we see any expressions of caution on election day representing a change in the company’s outlook.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

And UBS.

BE11:31am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Slightly ahead of consensus, in line with UBSe. Autotrader reported FY17 Group Revenues of +10% (9% ex additional days) to £311m (UBSe £315m, Cons £310m). Underlying operating profit was £207m (UBSe £208m, Cons £203m). Reported EPS was 15.6p (UBSe 15.6p, Cons 15.2p). Net debt at end of Mar-17 was £355m.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Total forecourts fell by 1.6% yoy, to 13296 (UBSe 13379, Cons 13390). Retailer ARPR increased by 12% to £1546 (UBSe £1558, Cons £1533). The main difference between reported ARPR and UBS forecasts was that average stock on site only increased by 3% vs UBSe of 5%.

BE11:31am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Autotrader guided for FY18 forecourt numbers to be flat or marginally down but stock overall to continue to grow. ARPR growth in FY18 is expected to increase by £130 or above per month, driven mainly by product. Consumer services revenue is expected to grow low single digit and Display advertising to grow double digit, but at a slower rate than recently. Autotrader has also guided for opex growth of mid-single digit and operating margins to rise further.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Neutral. Result broadly in line. FY18 ARPR guidance is positive but is dependent on execution on product levers (upsell/cross-sell). FY18 Opex growth guidance of mid-single digit is slightly above expectations (UBSe 4%, Cons 3%).

undefined
undefined
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Sorry, offscreen for a moment.

BE11:36am

Right! Back. Sorry. Unrelated to anything happening here.

BE11:36am

So, we're getting steered away from this IWG story.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

People familiar with things are claiming there's nothing in the rumour.

BE11:38am

So if it were true, it's now at a level of speculation where the Panel could legitimately demand a statement.

BE11:39am

And the gist we're getting from people is that we shouldn't expect any kind of statement.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Live price is up 2.6%.

undefined
BE11:40am

While in the sector, should probably mention Workspace.

11:39 am
Workspace Group PLC (WKP:LSE): Last: 914.95, up 38.45 (+4.39%), High: 919.50, Low: 870.00, Volume: 87.11k
BE11:40am

FY shows NAV up 4.2%, underlying profit up 15.5%.

BE11:40am

Outlook positive.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Though vague.

BE11:41am

Kempen are sellers, FWIW.

BE11:42am

Workspace published a set of good FY results this morning. Net rental income grew 6.9% YoY to £79.2m (E: £78.3m), whilst recurring PBT was up a slightly better than expected 15.5% YoY to £50.7m (E: £49.5m). As a result, recurring EPS came out at 30.6p (E: 30.2p), although the FY dividend was slightly lower than expected at 21.1p (E: 22.9p). The NAV was up 3.3% for the FY and 4.2% in H2 to 953p, which was 2% better than expected (E: 932p). The l-f-l rent roll increased a strong 13.7% to £56.9m, with growth in H2 slightly below H1 at 6.2% vs 7.1%. L-f-l rent per sf was up 12.9% for the year to £28.17, whilst occupancy was broadly stable at 90.3%. The portfolio value was up 2.1% for the FY, as a 6.7% increase in ERVs was partly offset by 10bps softening in equivalent yields, with a 3.0% increase in H2 offsetting a 0.9% decline in H1. The outlook from management did not contain any specific guidance, but remained confident with respect to the prospects for the business. With an LTV of 13%, Workspace is in good shape to deliver further growth from its substantial refurbishment pipeline and some recent acquisitions, which is reflected in the 40%+ growth in EPS we forecast for the business over the next two years. The question is how much to pay for this growth, as we expect the general economic outlook for London to slow, so at a 5.2% +2Yr EPS yield much of this already appears priced in, in our view.

11:43 am
undefined
BE11:43am

Oh, and Berendsen

Berendsen PLC (BRSN:LSE): Last: 1,202, up 95 (+8.58%), High: 1,219, Low: 1,193, Volume: 7.27m
11:46 am
BE11:46am

So, to recap. Berendsen management was certain it was going to deliver shareholder value by staying independent then Elis offered another 80p and management decided that independence wasn't so great after all.

BE11:47am

Perhaps this was all well stage managed. I mean, they had enough advisers onboard to make up a convincing "reluctantly concede" strategy.

BE11:48am

I mean .....

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Enquiries:

Berendsen

Pete Young, Head of Investor Relations +44 (0)7825 297 198

Credit Suisse (Financial adviser to Berendsen)

Jonathan Grundy Joe Hannon Vasyl Dutchak +44 (0)207 888 8888

Robert Constant Dwayne Lysaght Richard Walsh +44 (0)20 7742 4000

Mark Dickenson Philip Noblet Keith Welch +44(0) 207 991 8888

FTI Consulting

Richard Mountain +44 (0)20 3727 1374

Elis

Nicolas Buron +33 (0) 1 75 49 98 30

Brunswick (Public Relations Adviser to Elis)

Jonathan Glass Wendel Verbeek Alison Kay +44 (0) 20 7404 5959

Thomas Kamm Aurélia de Lapeyrouse +33 (0) 1 53 96 83 83

Lazard & Co., Limited (Financial Adviser to Elis)

William Rucker William Lawes Vasco Litchfield +44 (0) 20 7187 2000

Pierre Tattevin +33 (0) 1 44 13 01 11

Zaoui & Co Ltd (Financial Adviser to Elis)

Yoel Zaoui Michael Zaoui Serge Mouracade +44 (0) 20 7290 5580

Deutsche Bank (Financial Adviser and Corporate Broker to Elis)

Neil Collingridge Chris Raff / Simon Hollingsworth +44 (0) 20 7545 8000

BE11:48am

There's not much going on, certainly, but does this deal really need that much manpower?

BE11:49am

Have Peel Hunt to say, "fair outcome".

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Agreement in principle on a Recommended Possible Offer from Elis. The Boards of Elis and Berendsen have reached agreement in principle on the key terms of a possible recommended offer to be made by Elis for Berendsen. The Possible Offer comprises 540p in cash (vs 440p under the initial proposal) and 0.403 new Elis shares (value of 710p per share, based upon an Elis share price of €20.17 and a £:€ exchange rate of 1.145 vs the initial proposal of 0.426 new Elis shares, value 733p per share), which values each Berendsen share at 1,250p (vs 1,173p under the initial proposal). In addition, Berendsen shareholders will be entitled to a dividend of 11p, expected to be declared and paid by Berendsen in respect of H1 2017 (2016 interim dividend of 10.5p). The offer is 7% above the initial proposal and has a greater cash element (43% vs 37%). Elis is intending to offer a mix and match facility. The Possible Offer represents a 45% premium to Berendsen’s £8.64 close share price of 17 May, the last business day prior to the announcement of the initial proposal. The price offered equates to 18.6x 2018E EPS and 7.3x 2018E EBITDA. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, which currently holds c5% of Elis, has agreed to subscribe for 10.1m new Elis shares at €19.74 (an 11% discount to the closing price). The funds raised by the CPPIB Cash Placing will not be used to fund the cash proportion of the consideration, but will be used to repay borrowing incurred by Elis to finance the transaction. We estimate that the placing will reduce the net debt/EBITDA leverage ratio of the combined group by c0.2x. The Berendsen Board has indicated to Elis that it expects to recommend unanimously to Berendsen shareholders an offer on customary terms at the level and composition of the Possible Offer, subject to agreement on the conditions of the formal offer and completion of confirmatory due diligence. The announcement by Elis of a formal offer would require the satisfaction or waiver of the following pre-conditions: (1) formal unanimous recommendation of the offer by the Berendsen Board; and (2) the receipt of irrevocable undertakings to vote in favour of the transaction from members of the Berendsen Board in their capacity as shareholders. Valuation. We set fair value at 1,250p (from 908p previously) to reflect the level of the Possible Offer.

BE11:50am

And RBC.

BE11:51am

Having aggressively refused 1170p citing opportunism and significant undervaluation, Berendsen has accepted a sweetener from Elis of a revised 1250p bid with £5.40 in cash (100p more) and 0.403 Elis shares. This equates to a 45pc premium to pre-bid levels. Shareholders will also receive an 11p interim div. As we said in our recent note - we see this as an excellent price for shareholders, given the valuation versus peers (a very full 22x PE, 18x EV/EBITA) and the execution risks of the recovery programme at standalone Berendsen. We would urge shareholders to accept the bid.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The implied take-out multiples at 1250p make Johnson Service Group look quite good value. Putting this into perspective - JSG is
currently trading on a FY17E PE of 15x and EV/EBITA of 14x, a 32% discount on a PE basis and a 23% discount on EV/EBITA.
However, this will potentially signify more intense competition for JSG in the UK, (as we believe Elis are good flat linen operators and are not averse to being aggressive on price to take share, as Rentokil has found out in France). In our view, this deal could accelerate JSG’s consolidation plans – scale (and route-density) is key in this market and the group will want to be on the front foot. However in the near term, the group is also likely to be a key beneficiary of the distraction at Berendsen, especially with the capex roll-out plans and whether this will be maintained under new leadership. (Medium-term this does remove a potential suitor for JSG, who we continue to believe could be a takeover target at some point.)

Johnson Service Group PLC (JSG:LSE): Last: 120.50, down 1.5 (-1.23%), High: 122.00, Low: 120.25, Volume: 27.99k
undefined
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Let me have a scratch around sellside to see if we can get to the finish line that way.

BE11:58am

............. when I can stop typing offscreen for a moment.

BE11:58am

There's Jefferies on miners. Turning cautious on BHP.

11:59 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,178, up 7 (+0.60%), High: 1,185, Low: 1,169, Volume: 1.79m
BE11:59am

The balance sheet recap trade in mining is over, in our view, as is the Chinese stimulus-driven recovery in demand. Prices for some commodities should go higher due to structural factors (i.e., copper), but the macroeconomic cycle is no longer a clear positive. Given the increased risk, we downgrade BHP and S32 (from Buy to Hold) and VED and FMG (from Hold to Underperform). We reiterate our Buy ratings on GLEN, RIO and FCX due to company-specific drivers.

BE11:59am

Macro backdrop is cooling: The miners greatly benefited from Chinese stimulus-driven demand in '16 following a near hard landing in 2H15. Most miners recapitalized their balance sheets with asset sales and FCF. Some - including GLEN and FCX - issued equity as well. While balance sheets are no longer a serious concern, the end to Chinese stimulus is. However, a cyclical slowdown does not imply the death of mining. Some commodities, such as copper, lithium, cobalt and vanadium, will benefit from higher electric vehicle penetration and use of batteries in general. Copper should also benefit from a stronger consumer globally. Supply constraints in some cases will help as well (copper & coking coal). Meanwhile the outlook for iron ore continues to be a real concern, especially for higher cost producers.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Downgrading BHP, S32, VED and FMG: We have lowered our commodity price forecasts, EPS estimates and NPV-based target prices (Exhibits 5-7). We downgrade BHP (on valuation and commodity exposure) and S32 (on commodity exposure and operating risk) from Buy to Hold. Our analysis indicates that Fortescue and Vedanta are notably poorly positioned for an extended period of lower commodity prices, and we downgrade FMG and VED from Hold to Underperform. We maintain our Buy ratings on our top picks: Glencore (cyclical resilience in Marketing, leverage to copper and cobalt, capital return outlook), Rio (capital return outlook even in a weaker iron ore price environment) and Freeport (leverage to copper and potential resolution to the dispute with Indonesia).

Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 575.00, down 20 (-3.36%), High: 593.00, Low: 562.50, Volume: 1.12m
undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Okay, we made it through to midday.

BE12:03pm

Enjoy the ECB. And Coney.

BE12:05pm

See you back here tomorrow, for the New Era of a Better, Fairer, Strong and Stable Markets Live

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

(@Flaneur: nope, I meant the fair in New York.)

BE12:05pm

Until then, afternoon all.

BE11:24am
